name: sulfate pulp production, from softwood, unbleached | electricity, high voltage | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/26082/documentation

This dataset represents the Latin American production of unbleached kraft pulp, obtained from softwood for the year 2020. Industry data was used which was provided by the European Pulp Industry Sector Association AISBL (EPIS). The data represents a weighted average of the participating mills located in Latin America. The represented technology is considered state of the art for a Latin American average.;PULP is a wood-based raw material to make different paper, board and other products. The pulp, or fibers from the wood are separated in a kraft cooking process in a so-called fiber line. In a recovery line, the chemicals used in the cooking process are recovered to be used again and energy is produced. The third process is effluent treatment where gaseous and liquid discharges to the environment are continuously minimized and monitored.;MAIN END USES FOR MARKET PULP • Tissue (toilet paper) • Graphic papers • Specialty products • Packaging • Fluff pulp • Viscose • CMC etc. ;PRODUCTS GENERATED IN THE PULPING PROCESS include electricity;CAPACITIES Global production of unbleached kraft pulp was 36 million tonnes in 2021, of which around 2.3 million was dried, baled and sold to market.;SPECIES Softwood pulp is made from coniferous trees, most typically from different species of pine and spruce. Hardwood pulp is made from non-coniferous trees, in Nordic countries primarily of birch. Eucalyptus hardwood pulp is made exclusively of eucalyptus species.;CHARACTERISTICS Softwood fibers are long and slender and are used to give the paper and board products their strength properties. Hardwood fibers are short and can be rounder and their number per gram of pulp is much larger; they give the end product its smoothness, softness and optical properties like opacity (that you cannot see through the paper).

This activity starts with the transport of pulpwood to the pulp factory. The pulpwood input has an activity links to the supplying activities and is therefore not supplied via market dataset

The process includes transports to the pulp mill, wood handling, chemical pulping, and drying process, energy production on-site, recovery cycles of chemicals and internal waste water treatment. The following air emissions were reported in the study: CO2 (fossil and biogenic), SO2 (reported as S) and NOx. Next to these key emissions, additional emissions from on-site energy production from external and internal fuels were calculated, using emission profiles from ecoinvent combustion processes. Internal biogenic fuels are represented by the calculated emissions but do not have the corresponding fuel input from technosphere, because they are supplied from within the system boundaries. The amounts of internal fuels used in the process are: Black liquor(1.85E+04MJ/t) and bark (4.35E+03MJ/t). Black liquor was not included in the emissions calculations because no specific emission profiles, e.g., for the black liquor recovery process, were available. Emissions from these internal energy generation processes are therefore only reflected in the key emission factors provided by the industry, other emissions constitute a data gap. The activity ends when the kraft pulp is ready to be sold.
category: C:Manufacturing/17:Manufacture of paper and paper products/170:Manufacture of paper and paper products/1701:Manufacture of pulp, paper and paperboard

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data gathered in 2021 and represents data of 2020 values. Recent technology valid for the upcoming years.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data is coming from mills in Latin America.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Average Latin American technology in 2020 of kraft pulp production of unbleached pulp
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Industry data provided key emission factors for CO2 (biogenic), SO2, and NOx. Additional air emissions resulting from on-site energy production, i.e. the combustion of fuels, were calculated based on industrial heating datasets from the ecoinvent database. The following combustion processes were used: heavy fuel oil: heat production, heavy fuel oil, at industrial furnace 1MW, Europe without Switzerland; wood chips: heat production, wood chips from industry, at furnace 1000kW, CH
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Weighted average of several mills providing 82% of the Latin American capacity of unbleached kraft pulp from softwood.

exchanges.description: Estimation based on fuel input data and emission factors from corresponding ecoinvent fuel combustion (see "Extrapolations" comment). Apart from external fuel inputs, internal fuels such as black liquor are generated during the process and supply considerable amounts of process energy. Internal fuels are represented by the calculated emissions but do not have the corresponding fuel input from technosphere, because they are supplied from within the system boundaries. The amounts of internal fuels used in the process are: Black liquor(1.85E+04MJ/t) and bark (4.35E+03MJ/t). Black liquor was not included in the emissions calculations because no specific emission profiles were available. Emissions from this internal energy generation process are therefore only reflected in the key emission factors provided by the industry, other emissions constitute a data gap.

flow.name: Lead II
flow.category: Elementary flows/Emission to air/high population density

exchanges.description: This value represents a calculated value, i.e., it is not based on EPIS (2020) data. There was found to be an imbalance in carbon and therefore this value had to be recalculated to close the balance. The original amounts reported by EPIS (2020) is pine 2.268 (kg dry/kg). “softwood forestry, pine, sustainable forest management, GLO, 2010 – 2012” is used as a Proxy to represent pulpwood production in RLA.

The amounts of internal fuels used in the process are: Black liquor(1.85E+04MJ/t) and bark (4.35E+03MJ/t). Black liquor was not included in the emissions calculations because no specific emission profiles were available. Emissions from this internal energy generation process are therefore only reflected in the key emission factors provided by the industry, other emissions constitute a data gap.
